title: Adriana Aparecida da Silva
text:
Adriana Aparecida da Silva (born 22 July 1981) is a Brazilian <a href="long-distance%20runner">long-distance runner</a> who competes in <a href="half%20marathon">half marathon</a>s and <a href="marathon">marathon</a>s. She has represented her country at World Championship-level both on the roads and in cross country. She won two gold medals in the marathon at the <a href="2011%20Pan%20American%20Games">2011 Pan American Games</a> in <a href="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="2015%20Pan%20American%20Games">2015 Pan American Games</a> in <a href="Toronto">Toronto, Ontario</a>, Canada.
She is a member of <a href="Esporte%20Clube%20Pinheiros">Esporte Clube Pinheiros</a>.
Career.
Adriana da Silva was born in <a href="Cruzeiro%2C%20S%C3%A3o%20Paulo">Cruzeiro, São Paulo</a>, and started her career as a <a href="cross%20country%20runner">cross country runner</a>. She represented Brazil in the junior races at the <a href="IAAF%20World%20Cross%20Country%20Championships">IAAF World Cross Country Championships</a> in 1998 and 2000. Following a national title win in the half marathon, she made her first senior appearance on the world stage at the <a href="2004%20IAAF%20World%20Half%20Marathon%20Championships">2004 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships</a>, coming in 39th place.
After a break in her <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a> career, da Silva returned to action in 2008 and ran for Brazil at the <a href="2010%20IAAF%20World%20Cross%20Country%20Championships">2010 IAAF World Cross Country Championships</a>, ending the race in 82nd place. She made her marathon debut at the Santa Catarina Marathon in <a href="Florian%C3%B3polis">Florianópolis</a> and won on her first attempt, recording a time of 2:41:30 hours. She was selected for the Brazilian squad at the <a href="2009%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">2009 World Championships in Athletics</a> as a result and improved her best to 2:40:54 hours to finish 43rd in the Berlin race. In 2010, she came third at the <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20Marathon">São Paulo Marathon</a>, just two seconds outside of her personal best time. She won the Río de Janeiro Half Marathon in July and went on to have her highest global placing at the <a href="2010%20IAAF%20World%20Half%20Marathon%20Championships">2010 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships</a> in <a href="Nanning">Nanning</a>, where she was 25th in the rankings. The <a href="2010%20Berlin%20Marathon">2010 Berlin Marathon</a> in September saw her significantly improve her best with a finishing time of 2:32:30 hours for seventh place.
In 2011, she ran at the <a href="Vienna%20City%20Marathon">Vienna City Marathon</a> and was sixth with a time of 2:33:48 hours. Later that year, she won the South American title in the half marathon. The <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202011%20Pan%20American%20Games">2011 Pan American Games</a> saw her ascend to the peak of the regional scene as she won the marathon <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a> in a <a href="List%20of%20Pan%20American%20Games%20records%20in%20athletics">Games record</a> time of 2:36:37 hours, in spite of <a href="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>'s high altitude. She set a personal best of 2:29:17 hours at the 2012 <a href="Tokyo%20Marathon">Tokyo Marathon</a>, finishing ninth overall. She competed at the 2012 Summer Olympics, finishing 47th in a time of 2:33:15.
In 2015, she was the gold medalist in the marathon at the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202015%20Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> in <a href="Toronto">Toronto, Ontario</a>, Canada after the <a href="Peru">Peru</a>vian athletic <a href="Gladys%20Tejeda">Gladys Tejeda</a> lost her gold medal. She also broke the <a href="List%20of%20Pan%20American%20Games%20records%20in%20athletics">Games record</a> with a time of 2:35:40 hours.
